name: Bodhisattva
shortDescription: Enlightened being who delays final nirvana to compassionately liberate all sentient beings from suffering
longDescription: A Bodhisattva (Sanskrit: ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ß‡§ø‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ, 'enlightenment being') is a being who has generated bodhicitta‚Äîthe awakened mind that aspires to achieve enlightenment for the benefit of all sentient beings. The Bodhisattva ideal is the central spiritual aspiration of Mahayana Buddhism, contrasting with the Arhat ideal of Theravada. While Arhats seek personal liberation from samsara, Bodhisattvas take the great vow to remain in the cycle of rebirth until all beings are freed from suffering. They cultivate the Six Perfections (Paramitas): generosity, ethical conduct, patience, diligence, meditation, and wisdom. Great Bodhisattvas like Avalokiteshvara (compassion), Manjushri (wisdom), and Tara (swift protection) are revered as celestial beings who respond to prayers and guide practitioners. The Bodhisattva path involves progressing through ten stages (bhumis) of realization, from the initial generation of bodhicitta to the final stage just before Buddhahood. The defining characteristic is compassion (karuna) united with wisdom (prajna), embodying the Mahayana principle that one cannot be fully enlightened while others suffer.

bodhicitta.name: Bodhicitta
bodhicitta.description: The awakened mind of enlightenment - the aspiration to achieve Buddhahood for the benefit of all beings. Has two aspects: aspiration (wishing to achieve enlightenment for others) and application (actively practicing the path).

greatVow.name: The Great Vow
greatVow.description: Bodhisattvas take vows to save all sentient beings, knowing this task is infinite. Classic formulation: 'Beings are numberless, I vow to save them. Delusions are inexhaustible, I vow to end them. Dharma gates are boundless, I vow to enter them. Buddha's way is unsurpassable, I vow to become it.'

sixParamitas.name: Six Perfections (Paramitas)
sixParamitas.description: The six transcendent virtues cultivated by Bodhisattvas

perfections.name: Dana (Generosity)
perfections.description: Giving of material goods, Dharma teachings, and fearlessness

perfections.name: Shila (Ethical Conduct)
perfections.description: Moral discipline, keeping precepts, avoiding harm

perfections.name: Kshanti (Patience)
perfections.description: Forbearance under harm, patience with Dharma study, patience with the nature of reality

perfections.name: Virya (Diligence)
perfections.description: Joyful perseverance in practice, overcoming laziness

perfections.name: Dhyana (Meditation)
perfections.description: Cultivation of concentration, absorption, and meditative stability

perfections.name: Prajna (Wisdom)
perfections.description: Transcendent wisdom realizing emptiness and the nature of reality

tenBhumis.name: Ten Stages (Dashabhumika)
stages: Difficult to Train (Sudurjaya) - Skillful means perfection
Directly Facing (Abhimukhi) - Wisdom of dependent origination
Gone Afar (Durangama) - Mastery of skillful means
Immovable (Achala) - Cannot be moved from virtue
Good Discriminating Wisdom (Sadhumati) - Perfect teaching abilities
Cloud of Dharma (Dharmamegha) - Final stage before Buddhahood

celestialBodhisattvas.description: Advanced Bodhisattvas who have achieved high realization and assist beings from pure lands

earthlyBodhisattvas.description: Practitioners who have generated bodhicitta and are progressing on the path
examples: Anyone who has taken Bodhisattva vows
